_metadata.title: Cape Town Biodiversity Offset Rules Configuration

sources.name: National Biodiversity Offset Guideline (2023)
sources.authority: Department of Forestry, Fisheries and the Environment (DFFE)
sources.note: National guideline published under NEMA Section 24J. Not legally binding but guides EIA offset decisions.

sources.name: Western Cape Provincial Guideline on Biodiversity Offsets (2007, revised 2011)
sources.authority: Western Cape Department of Environmental Affairs and Development Planning
sources.note: First provincial offset guideline in South Africa. Establishes basic offset ratios by ecosystem threat status.

sources.name: Cape Town BioNet 2024 (Terrestrial Biodiversity Network)
sources.reference: City of Cape Town Open Data Portal
sources.authority: City of Cape Town Biodiversity Management Branch
sources.note: CBA categories extracted from the live BioNet feature service.

sources.name: National Biodiversity Assessment 2018 / SANBI Ecosystem Status 2011
sources.note: Ecosystem threat status classifications for Cape Town vegetation types.

_metadata.disclaimer: This configuration is derived from publicly available policy documents and open data. It is intended for indicative/screening purposes only and does NOT constitute legal or environmental consulting advice. Actual offset requirements are determined through the EIA process on a case-by-case basis by the competent authority.

PA.name: Protected Area
PA.full_description: Formally protected under the Protected Areas Act or reserved for Biodiversity Management Branch and in process for proclamation. Managed for biodiversity conservation.
PA.note: No development permitted. Statutory conservation management required.
PA.bionet_significance: International significance for biodiversity and landscape features.

CA.name: Conservation Area
CA.full_description: Not formally protected under the Protected Areas Act. Includes areas managed for biodiversity conservation with short term stewardship agreements.
CA.note: Managed for conservation. Should be upgraded to Protected Area where appropriate.
CA.bionet_significance: International significance for biodiversity and landscape features.

CBA_1a.name: Critical Biodiversity Area 1a (Irreplaceable - High/Medium Condition)
CBA_1a.full_description: Natural or near-natural ecological condition required to conserve a viable representative sample of this ecosystem type. Irreplaceable for meeting biodiversity targets. Includes Core Flora sites.
CBA_1a.note: No-go area for development. Offsets not considered because residual impacts would be of exceptionally high significance. National guideline states offsets are not appropriate where impacts are on irreplaceable biodiversity.
CBA_1a.bionet_significance: International significance for biodiversity and landscape features. Loss will result in the inability to attain biodiversity targets and could lead to species extinction.

CBA_1b.name: Critical Biodiversity Area 1b (Irreplaceable - Low Condition, High Selection)
CBA_1b.full_description: Low ecological condition required to conserve a viable representative sample of this ecosystem type. Irreplaceable for meeting biodiversity targets.
CBA_1b.ratio_description: 30 hectares of offset land required per 1 hectare of impact (30:1)
CBA_1b.note: Only considered in exceptional circumstances where avoidance is demonstrably impossible. The 30:1 ratio derives from the Western Cape Provincial Guideline for Critically Endangered ecosystems. Rehabilitation may be required in addition to the offset.

CBA_1c.name: Critical Biodiversity Area 1c (Irreplaceable - Low Condition, Connectivity)
CBA_1c.full_description: Irreplaceable low condition site selected for connectivity purposes.
CBA_1c.note: Connectivity function means offset must be like-for-like in landscape position. Rehabilitation-focused offset may be appropriate.

CBA_2.name: Critical Biodiversity Area 2 (Optimal Selection)
CBA_2.full_description: Selected as the best option for meeting biodiversity targets based on complementarity, spatial efficiency, connectivity and/or avoidance of conflict with other uses.
CBA_2.ratio_description: 20 hectares of offset land required per 1 hectare of impact (20:1) for Endangered ecosystems; ratio adjusted by ecosystem threat status
CBA_2.trade_down_conditions: Offset may be 'traded down' where the development site is within the Urban Development Edge and the offset secures higher-priority habitat (CBA 1 or PA-quality land).
CBA_2.note: Offset ratio is based on Endangered ecosystem baseline. Actual ratio adjusted by ecosystem threat status multiplier. These are optimal (not irreplaceable) selections, so alternative spatial configurations may exist.

ESA_1.name: Ecological Support Area 1 (Natural/Semi-natural)
ESA_1.full_description: Natural/semi-natural ecological condition. Must be maintained in a semi-natural ecological condition. Further deterioration must be avoided, to support conservation of ecosystems and species and maintain ecologically functional landscapes.
ESA_1.ratio_description: 5 hectares of offset per 1 hectare of impact (5:1) baseline for Vulnerable ecosystems
ESA_1.note: Offset required to maintain ecological processes (fire regime, animal movement, edge effects). Ratio adjusted by specific ecological function being impacted.

ESA_2.name: Ecological Support Area 2 (Intensively Modified)
ESA_2.full_description: Intensively modified ecological condition. Must be maintained in semi-natural ecological condition. Further deterioration must be avoided, to support the conservation of ecosystems and species to maintain ecologically functional landscapes.
ESA_2.ratio_description: 3:1 baseline ratio; rehabilitation-focused offset may substitute for land-based offset
ESA_2.note: Already degraded. Offset emphasis is on rehabilitation and restoration rather than land acquisition. Maintaining ecological function is the priority.

ONA.name: Other Natural Area
ONA.full_description: Natural area that has not been selected to meet biodiversity targets for ecosystem types, species or ecological processes.
ONA.note: No biodiversity offset required. Standard EIA conditions apply. Alien invasive control and ecologically sound fire management still recommended.

ecosystem_threat_status_ratios._description: Basic offset ratios from the Western Cape Provincial Guideline on Biodiversity Offsets (DEA&DP 2007, Brownlie et al.). The ratio represents hectares of offset land required per hectare of development impact. These are applied as multipliers to the CBA base ratio.
ecosystem_threat_status_ratios._formula: Offset Area = Impact Area × base_ratio × ecosystem_threat_multiplier × condition_multiplier

CR.offset_consideration: Exceptional circumstances only. National guideline states offsets not appropriate for irreplaceable biodiversity. Western Cape guideline applies 30:1 only where avoidance has been demonstrably exhausted.
CR.note: Ecosystems with <50% remaining should generally be considered unsuitable for offsetting (no-go). Most CR ecosystems in Cape Town have <20% remaining.

EN.offset_consideration: Offsets applicable with stringent conditions. Like-for-like ecosystem type offset required.
EN.note: Offset must secure the same ecosystem type or a higher-priority (more threatened) type.

VU.offset_consideration: Offsets applicable. Trading down to secure more threatened ecosystem types may be acceptable.
VU.note: Lower ratio reflects greater remaining extent and lower extinction risk.

LT.offset_consideration: Offset rarely required unless specific species or processes are impacted.
LT.note: Ecosystems with adequate remaining extent. Standard mitigation hierarchy applies.

cape_town_ecosystem_types._description: Vegetation types occurring within the City of Cape Town municipal area, with their SANBI ecosystem threat status (NBA 2018 / SANBI Ecosystem Status 2011). Extracted from CCT Open Data Portal SANBI Vegetation Ecosystem Status 2011 layer.

critically_endangered.name: Atlantis Sand Fynbos
critically_endangered.offset_notes: Large remnant but heavily fragmented. Key conservation land bank area (Atlantis).

critically_endangered.name: Cape Flats Sand Fynbos
critically_endangered.offset_notes: Less than 1% conserved. Endemic to Cape Town. 15% of original extent remaining. Extremely high offset cost.

critically_endangered.name: Swartland Shale Renosterveld
critically_endangered.offset_notes: Highly fragmented on agricultural land. Very limited offset opportunities.

critically_endangered.name: Peninsula Granite Fynbos - South
critically_endangered.offset_notes: Concentrated in high-value residential areas (Constantia, Hout Bay).

endangered.name: Peninsula Sandstone Fynbos
endangered.offset_notes: Largest remaining vegetation type in CT. Concentrated in Table Mountain National Park.

endangered.name: Cape Flats Dune Strandveld - West Coast
Cape Flats Dune Strandveld - False Bay
endangered.offset_notes: False Bay form approaching Critically Endangered. Only 30% remaining with 19% in good condition.

vulnerable.name: Cape Lowland Freshwater Wetlands
vulnerable.offset_notes: SANBI 2011 classifies as VU; more recent assessments (Wikipedia/SANBI) suggest CR. Freshwater wetland offsets are particularly complex due to hydrological connectivity requirements.

condition_multipliers._description: Multipliers applied based on the ecological condition of the habitat being impacted. Applied on top of the ecosystem threat status ratio. From the BioNet habitat condition field (HBT_CNDT).

Natural.description: Pristine or near-pristine condition. Full offset ratio applies.

Good.description: Good ecological condition with minor disturbance. Full ratio applies.

Fair.description: Moderately degraded but restorable. Reduced ratio reflects lower current biodiversity value.

Poor.description: Significantly degraded. Rehabilitation may be more appropriate than land-based offset.

Irreversibly modified.description: No natural habitat remaining. No biodiversity offset required.

urban_edge_rules._description: The Urban Development Edge affects offset calculations. Developments inside the edge may receive reduced offset requirements or be allowed to 'trade down' to offset in higher-priority areas.

inside_urban_edge.note: 20% reduction in offset ratio may be applied for developments within the Urban Development Edge, provided the offset secures higher-priority habitat outside the edge.

outside_urban_edge.note: 20% increase in offset ratio for developments outside the Urban Development Edge, reflecting higher ecological sensitivity and cumulative impact risk.

offset_cost_estimation._description: Indicative cost parameters for offset calculations. Actual costs vary significantly based on land values, management requirements, and endowment funding.

conservation_land_bank.description: City of Cape Town Conservation Land Bank (Atlantis, Macassar East)
conservation_land_bank.note: Pre-secured offset land held by the City. Costs based on municipal valuation + management endowment.

private_land_cba1.note: Highly variable. Atlantic Seaboard and Southern Suburbs significantly more expensive.

management_endowment_per_ha.description: Capital sum required to fund in-perpetuity management of offset site
management_endowment_per_ha.note: Based on CapeNature and SANParks management cost benchmarks. Covers alien clearing, fire management, monitoring.

offset_cost_estimation.note: National guideline requires offset land to be secured for at least 99 years through a biodiversity stewardship agreement or formal protected area declaration.

calculation_engine._description: Formula and parameters for the calculation engine to compute offset requirements.
steps: 1. Determine CBA category of the impact site from BioNet layer
2. Look up ecosystem threat status from SANBI vegetation type
4. Apply condition_multiplier based on BioNet HBT_CNDT field
5. Apply urban_edge_adjustment based on whether site is inside/outside Urban Development Edge
6. Calculate: offset_hectares = impact_area × base_ratio × condition_multiplier × urban_edge_adjustment
8. Identify matching offset sites from Conservation Land Bank or CBA areas of same ecosystem type

special_rules.cr_ecosystem_warning: Ecosystems classified as Critically Endangered with <20% remaining extent should be flagged as potential no-go areas regardless of CBA category. The national guideline states offsets are not appropriate for irreplaceable biodiversity.
